awd_titl_txt: AI Institute: Planning: TRustworthy Autonomous Systems Engineering (TRASE)
awd_abstract_narration:
In many ways, autonomy is the holy grail of artificial intelligence (AI). While tremendous advances towards this ultimate goal have been made across a number of disciplines, and for a number of applications, general-purpose autonomy remains elusive. Indeed, even when we focus on specific classes of applications, such as autonomous driving, numerous gaps remain. One fundamental challenge shared by many autonomous systems is to ensure that autonomous behavior is trustworthy: that is, safe, reliable, secure, and fair. This planning grant is a stepping stone towards an AI institute devoted to foundational and use-inspired advances in TRustworthy Autonomous Systems Engineering.  The institute would be focused on four research themes: 1) trustworthy AI integration in autonomous systems, 2) trustworthy platforms for real-time AI in autonomous systems, 3) trustworthy multiagent systems, and 4) accountable autonomy. Each of these will yield important advances in understanding the design of trustworthy systems in which AI is embodied in an open-loop framework involving perception, planning, and control. Furthermore, these advances will be coupled with use-inspired research in areas such as autonomous driving and drones, creating a virtuous cycle with applications directing fundamental research, and benefiting directly from it.
 
This project will aim to create a community of stakeholders---the TRASE Innovation Ecosystem---focusing on trustworthy autonomous systems, with implications for a broad range of applications, from autonomous driving to autonomous flight. In addition, the institute will yield transformative educational advances in the form of new materials for courses and programs that train students in the design and analysis of autonomous systems. The vision is to develop innovative educational components, such as competitions, and integrated student-industry-research teams that coalesce around common TRASE-relevant problems. Finally, educational collaborations will be established with minority-serving institutions, such as St Louis Community College (Florissant Campus) to broaden participation in computing in general, and in trustworthy autonomous systems engineering in particular.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

por.por_cntn:
This project had four goals: 1) design and execute pilot research projects for the TRASE AI Institute proposal, 2) create tighter collaborations within the team, 3)  Begin academic and industry outreach, 3) develop a pilot summer school for girls, and 4) develop infrastructure for the AI Institute.

Broadly, the central goal of this grant was to develop capabilities for submitting a proposal to the AI Institutes program, including team building, research, and educational activities, as well as development of infrastructure.  Our first set of activities centered around foundational research advances in trustworthy autonomy.  To this end, we published more than 25 scholarly articles tackling issues such as formal verification of machine learning (especially computer vision) embodied in autonomous systems (ICLR, ACC), robust learning and control (ICLR, ACC, AAAI, ICML, NeurIPS, CVPR, WACV), privacy of machine learning (S&P), value alignment (NeurIPS), and real-time systems (RTNS, ISSRE).

Our second set of activities involved team-building, which we promoted through collaborative pilot grants to individual projects aligned with the aims of developing trustworthy autonomous systems.  Four such pilots were ultimately developed, and each resulted in important research advances to support the full AI Institute proposal submission.  Moreover, the project ultimately yielded numerous joint publications among the planning grant collaborators.

Our third activity was to develop and support a week-long summer camp for underrepresented high school students.  We piloted this camp the first summer, and repriesed it the second summer, with topics including AI, autonomous, HCI, and visualization.

Our fourth activity was to stimulate broad community interest in Trustworthy Autonomous Systems. To this end, we organized two workshos.  The first was a part of the CPS PI meeting, and features prominent invited speakers including Naira Hovakimyan (a key investigator for this project). The second was a AAAI TRASE-22 workshop on trustworthy autonomous systems engineering. The workshop was extremely successful, with over 100 registrations.

Our fifth activity was to develop testbed infrastructure to support the full proposal.  To this end, we developed a physical testbed for F1/10 vehicle autonomous driving, focusing on perceptual complexity one would encounter in perceptually rich urban environments.

Our sixth activity was to train students across the participating institutions in interdisciplinary engineering research on trustworthy autonomy.  This was a highly successful endeavor, with 8 PhD students and 4 undergraduate students ultimately taking part in grant-related activities.

Finally, we developed and submitted an AI Institutes TRASE proposal, which was invited to the full proposal submission (to the Trustworthy AI theme).


Last Modified: 12/20/2023
Modified by: Yevgeniy Vorobeychik
